body:
compiling passed, but there is strange link error:

```
dmlc-core/libdmlc.a: error adding symbols: File format not recognized
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
make: *** [lib/libmxnet.so] Error 1
```
@Normal network training should be fixed in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/713
I will try to split the raw data

Yes I checked.

#Grep

```
guillaume ) grep stack /etc/R/Makeconf

# configure  '--prefix=/usr' '--with-cairo' '--with-jpeglib' '--with-readline' '--with-tcltk' '--with-system-
bzlib' '--with-system-pcre' '--with-system-zlib' '--mandir=/usr/share/man' '--infodir=/usr/share/info' 
'--datadir=/usr/share/R/share' '--includedir=/usr/share/R/include' '--with-blas' '--with-lapack' 
'--enable-R-profiling' '--enable-R-shlib' '--enable-memory-profiling' '--without-recommended-
packages' '--build' 'x86_64-linux-gnu' 'build_alias=x86_64-linux-gnu' 'R_PRINTCMD=/usr/bin/lpr' 
'R_PAPERSIZE=letter' 'R_BROWSER=xdg-open' 'LIBnn=lib' 'JAVA_HOME=/usr/lib/jvm
/default-java' 'CC=gcc -std=gnu99' 'CFLAGS=-g -O2 -fstack-protector-strong -Wformat 
-Werror=format-security -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 -g' 'LDFLAGS=-Wl,-z,relro' 'CPPFLAGS=' 
'F77=gfortran' 'FFLAGS=-g -O2 -fstack-protector-strong' 'CXX=g++' 'CXXFLAGS=-g -O2 -fstack-
protector-strong -Wformat -Werror=format-security -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 -g' 'FC=gfortran' 
'FCFLAGS=-g -O2 -fstack-protector-strong'

CFLAGS = -g -O2 -fstack-protector-strong -Wformat -Werror=format-security 
-D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 -g $(LTO)

CXXFLAGS = -g -O2 -fstack-protector-strong -Wformat -Werror=format-security 
-D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 -g $(LTO)

CXX1XFLAGS = -g -O2 -fstack-protector-strong -Wformat -Werror=format-security 
-D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 -g

FCFLAGS = -g -O2 -fstack-protector-strong $(LTO)

FFLAGS = -g -O2 -fstack-protector-strong $(LTO)

SAFE_FFLAGS = -g -O2 -fstack-protector-strong -ffloat-store`
```

I added

```
CFLAGS=-g -O2 -Wformat -Werror=format-security -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 -g

CXXFLAGS=-g -O2 -Wformat -Werror=format-security -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 -g

CXXXFLGAGS=-g -O2 -Wformat -Werror=format-security -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 -g
```

to `~/.R/Makevars`

The package then compiles but fails to load, R crashes. I'll continue to investigate
Thank you . I finally solve this problem by download the OpenCV tar and make && install it

/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lcblas
collect2: 错误：ld 返回 1
make: **\* [lib/libmxnet.so] 错误 1

Also I have across the same question at ubuntu OS. I have solved it by changing LD_LIBRARY_PATH environment variable. I set LD_LIBRARY_PATH="where the libcudart.7.0.5 is". If you don't know how to change environment variable, the links following may help: https://help.ubuntu.com/community/EnvironmentVariables
http://serverfault.com/questions/201709/how-to-set-ld-library-path-in-ubuntu 
may it help somebody.

/usr/bin/ld: /usr/lib/../lib64/libcblas.a(cblas_sgemm.o): relocation R_X86_64_32 against `.rodata.str1.1' can not be used when making a shared object; recompile with -fPIC
/usr/lib/../lib64/libcblas.a: could not read symbols: Bad value
collect2: 错误：ld 返回 1
make: **\* [lib/libmxnet.so] 错误 1
I think mxnet currently is not able to handle general sparse matrix yet. You will probably have to convert each mini-batch data into dense matrix.
@kelelexu Can you provide a reproducible case for this?
I think ELU should be put at https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/activation-inl.h , and we can put leaky ELU here.
I double checked and please ignore my last message. I posted when I was just awake. This LGTM
Can you post the new log?

Thanks for identifying this. I was able to uninstall the brew installed version (wish I would have realized brew could install it first!), but I still have opencv installed through the process I followed here: http://blogs.wcode.org/2014/10/howto-install-build-and-use-opencv-macosx-10-10/ The files are located in my usr/local/lib folder and I'm not quite sure how to properly uninstall them. It appears that Xcode now only comes with SDK10.11 which is the the underlying cause of the incompatibility (since I pointed to this SDK in Cmake and I'm using OS 10.10.5). When I try to simply delete the opencv files in my usr/local/lib folder and then use brew to install opencv, I get this
[this.txt](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/files/44124/output2.txt) error running make -j4. Is there a way to uninstall this incorrectly compiled version or point to the brew-installed version of opencv? 

Thanks.

I'll try to replicate it, it didn't give any errors at the time, just hanged until manually killed.

Apparently I can install the R package by using GCC 5.2 ( so the version R / RCpp was built against ) and everything works as long as you use mx.cpu(). If you try to use mx.gpu() the error is:

```
Start training with 1 devices
[18:48:34] ./dmlc-core/include/dmlc/././logging.h:208: [18:48:34] src/storage/storage.cc:43: Please compile with CUDA enabled
Erreur : [18:48:34] src/storage/storage.cc:43: Please compile with CUDA enabled
```

I wonder if some file wasn't updated correctly because libmxnet.so definitely includes the CUDA symbols.

I nuked my mxnet folder and recloned it cleanly to rebuild it, currently there seems to be some problems^\* with the compilation so if it doesn't work I'll just revert to yesterday commits

EDIT: ^\* Problem found: it was the user, who forgot to re-set USE_CUDA = 1. Still the above error though, from a clean install when the python test clearly shows cuda is working.

This is a little puzzling

I have change the config.mk

 USE_DIST_KVSTORE = 1

what the problem ?

Sorry for this.

I am on travel now and I will look into this more closely after coming back to lab.
@mli could you please look into this?
please `make clean_all` first
please run `git submodule update`
Could you provide more details about the problem? Like the code snipplet? so we could give further help.
Does this happen each time you run the code? I have this problem before but when you run the code the second time, it won't stuck.

Two networks are trained in different way: cxxnet is using manually learning rate reduce. This example is  using factor reduction. As the reduction factor is 0.94 per epoch, in this figure, final learning rate is: 0.002266. While in cxxnet example, the final learning rate is much smaller than this value.
@antinucleon Really looking forward to it!
I'm not sure how gradients should be computed for these functions. Do you have reference?
I see, thank you
@pluskid  I see thanks! But that will make  sparse matrix vector multiplication too slow..

I run "git submodule update" but don't work
I change the ps-lite branch to dev, and work
I will try "make clean_all"

env:
1. g++ 4.8
2. cuda 7.0

execution:
1. git pull
2. git submodule update

The library needed is actually vcomp120.dll, which unfortunately cannot be
statically linked. I will figure out if we can include it in the package.
(if license allows us).

@piiswrong yes ,this is a problem . I am find reference 
https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/python/ops/math_grad.py#L441
should be fixed by #724 please have a `git pull`
@antinucleon probably this is one of the reason why our lstm isn't fast as expected?
Will check it tomorrow. Today & tomorrow morning I am benchmarking ELU.
OK, I will give a code snippet.
the problem has solved

Actually, convolutional autoencoder networks don't have to use the pooling and unpooling layers. Simply stacking several conv layers and then a few deconv layers together is alright. Just for a little more fun, they can be arbitrarily interleaved!
Yes！If you are using `write`, you can safely remove reset gradient code at the end of epoch
I mean, if I am using 'write' for the lstm, should it produce the same (and correct) result as using 'add' ? If that's the case, where is 'add' useful? Thanks !

hmm. I think I see what you mean, the 'add' only make difference when we call updater(idx, grad, weight).  
Using write will overwrite the gradient inside that call, whereas using 'add' will add to that. So I guess the engine will itself add up gradients to the same parameter when we call backward, which means that using 'write' is also correct for lstm in this case.

I make a mistake 
I complie mxnet on a machine,and use command rsync to the cluster, after I execute "cd python; python setup install", problem solved.

PS:
please close the issue, it's a mistake

i generally do not suggest to use python setup install since we update the codes frequently, especially for distributed training. a better way is just copy the .so and files, see the instruction above 

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/image-classification#predict
Do you have cuda libraries in your LD_LIBRARY_PATH?

YES， I have added, I found 
nm libmxnet.so  | grep culibosOnce
                 U culibosOnce
nm /usr/local/cuda/lib64/libculibos.a | grep culibosOnce
00000000000006a0 T culibosOnce
But there isn't libculibos.so. (CUDA version 7.5)

I think 'add' means the calculated gradient should be added to rather than written to the gradient variable. This is useful for RNN since RNN will calculate 't' ('t' is the number of unrolling length) gradients of the gate parameters, and all these gradients should be accumulated to update the gate parameters. In fact, I am quite surprised that the 'write' strategy gives the same result as 'add' strategy. Let me look into it.

Hi,

Thanks for your contribution!

-Minjie
Have added you to the [contributor list](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/CONTRIBUTORS.md).

@Strateus Could you try the latest version, or download the binary distribution from https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/releases/tag/weekly_binary_build? The bug was somehow resolved on my machine, though I am not sure by which commit.

I found this in the nvidia document:
"Note that libculibos.a is not needed when the shared version of these libraries is
used."
So I'm totally confused.
This should have been fixed. I included vcomp120.dll in the new packages. @phunterlau @thirdwing
Is it related to this? #568
I'm still not sure about this, but since tensorflow is doing the same thing, maybe we can merge is first. @tqchen what do you think?

nm libmxnet.so | grep culibosOnce on my machine returns nothing. Do you have any custom CCFLAGS or LDFLAGS?
Maybe try make clean_all, pull mxnet and update submodule, then build everything again?

Identity should be OK approximately as they are functions. I can hardly imagine things like ciel and floor can have a gradient. I guess alternatively we should not register the gradient, and leave them empty
So gradient is not defined for these functions
Looks nice, @piiswrong can you do another round of review and merge it in? Also cc @sneakerkg who did gradient checker before

This could be the reason, because the weight is binded with a shared variable, and current graph optimizer is yet not smart enough to change the gradient summation to an addto to the original variable.
 Either we directly bind by ndarray, or make the graph executor smarter to handle the addto case more gracefully
thx @mli  I will use the way you recommend
I was also got by this GPU memory problem with vgg network.

I think there is either a bug with memory allocation or calculation of required memory. I suspect the later.
A simple way to check would be to comment out the memory requirement checking code and see if it goes out of memory.
It's my fault. Thanks @piiswrong
@tqchen  I tried not to register the gradient function, but could not pass the test.
I've just installed and got the same error when trying regression.

[code.txt](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/files/44850/code.txt)

Auto detect layout of input matrix, use rowmajor..
 Show Traceback

 Rerun with Debug
 Error in mx.ctx.default() : 
  object 'mx.ctx.internal.default.value' not found

Now i have some error during compilation: 

```
Error   196 error C2064: term does not evaluate to a function taking 2 arguments    C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 12.0\VC\include\xrefwrap 283 1   mxnet
```

Any suggestions?

for example:

``` python
import mxnet as mx
import cPickle
def write_onserver():
    ctxdev = mx.gpu(1)
    num = mx.nd.ones((10, 4), ctx=ctxdev)
    cPickle.dump(num, open('hi.bin', 'wb'))

def read_onlaptop():
    num = cPickle.load(open('hi.bin', 'rb'))
    print num.asnumpy()
```

run  `write_onserver` on the gpu1 of server(server has several gpus). and then copy the `hi.bin` to the local laptop. my laptop only have 1 gpu, then run `read_onlaptop`. It will be failed.
But, If I run `write_onserver` on the gpu0 of server, and then copy `hi.bin` to the local laptop. then run `read_onlaptop`. It will be success.
Where i can find this code to comment out?
The PR for Caffe has some changes that are worth keeping an eye on: https://github.com/BVLC/caffe/pull/3388/

@kimquy06 Sorry I can't reproduce this error any more.

Can you tell me your OS and R version? If you are on Linux/Mac, the compiler version will be also useful.

Can you try to not use mxnet training in a for loop? It should work.

Error in a for loop or in a function is a known issue on some version of R.

OK, I will have a try and give a feedback later. Thanks so much.

I am the person who should say sorry.

I think I can give you a temporary fix. Can you run `init.context.default()`  first and your code?

I will fix this soon.

This is because pickle is being royal to the device of the array. You can copy the parameters to cpu first before you save the parameters, which is lone additional line. This is also what was happening in the background when you pickle

``` python
numcpu = num.copyto(mx.cpu())
cPickle.dump(num, open('hi.bin', 'wb'))
```
You need to remove the gradient(backward test), since gradient is not available
Error: could not find function "init.context.default"

The examples under notebooks are outdated. You are welcome to submit a fix or use examples under image-classification. 

If you want to fix this, I suggest changing the name of SoftmaxOutput to softmax
Which version of R you are using? Can you send me the data?
are you using make/os.mk?
You mean RBM? not yet
which blas are you using. Could you try atlas? sudo apt-get install libatlas-dev and change USE_BLAS to atlas

I do not get why was this ticket closed. Was the feature implemented ?
Please use this example to train CIFAR-Network; https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/image-classification
I removed the gradient function, but I'm afraid it can't work well with other ops..

Thanks, this is merged. I can hardly imagine how can gradient can be taken on these functions, the identity could only mean an approximate version of such gradient. We can always add it back when it is needed :)

Since `floor` and `ceil`are piecewise functions they should differentiate to 0 if the numer is _not_ and integer and the derivative is undefined for integers (because of the discontinuity). http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=gradient+of+floor%28x%29 

If such a gradient would be helpful is another question.

This is a bug bring in recently. Fixing...
